awd_abstract_narration:
As the Internet emerges as the platform for computation, we have become increasingly reliant on cryptography to provide privacy and security in many of our day-to-day activities. We rely on cryptographic protocols to protect our credit card numbers from hackers in electronic transactions and our personal information from unauthorized access on online social networks. However, the design of many cryptosystems do not adequately account for new computational and cryptographic attacks made possible by advances in quantum computing and complex protocol interactions on the Internet. The focus of this project lies in the design and analysis of new cryptographic protocols that address these new attacks.

The research is centered around two goals: (1) to develop cryptosystems from large classes of intractability assumptions as viable alternatives to the widely-used factorization-based cryptosystems; (2) to obtain new techniques and efficient protocols secure against coordinated attacks amidst concurrent protocol executions.

This research is expected to develop ideas and techniques which hold the potential to bridge the gap between theory and practice in cryptography, and to fundamentally change the way we communicate, compute and collaborate. To ensure broader impact of this research, this project also encompasses a program of educational and outreach activities, including curriculum development (with an emphasis on new pedagogical approaches) as well as collaboration and regular exchanges with research institutions in the New York area and abroad.

por.por_cntn:
As the Internet emerges as the platform for computation, we have
become increasingly reliant on cryptography to provide privacy and
security in many of our day-to-day activities. We rely on
cryptographic protocols to protect our credit card numbers from
hackers in electronic transactions and our personal information from
unauthorized access on online social networks. In this project, we
designed and analyzed new cryptographic protocols to address new
computational and cryptographic attacks made possible by advances in
quantum computing and complex protocol interactions on the Internet.

One of the highlights of the project pertains to SSL/TLS, the de facto
standard for secure Internet communications. Originally deployed in
web browsers for https connections, SSL/TLS is now also widely used on
e-commerce sites for processing payments and in Android and iOS mobile
apps. The main purpose of SSL/TLS is to provide confidentiality and
authenticity for communications between the client and the server. In
the course of the project, we provided an analysis of the
cryptographic core of TLS in the most common configuration with RSA
PKCS #1v1.5 encryption.

In addition, we also made significant progress in the field of
functional encryption: this is an emerging paradigm for public-key
encryption that enables more fine-grained access control to encrypted
data, so that only individuals satisfying a certain policy can decrypt
and access the data. In particular, we presented the first functional
encryption scheme that supports the class of all (polynomial-time
computable) access policies. Our scheme achieves a strong notion of
security against collusion attacks, as long as the problem of decoding
random linear codes remains intractable; this is widely believed to be
true even against quantum computers, short of an algorithmic
break-through in coding theory.

This project also encompassed a program of educational and outreach
activities, including curriculum development (with an emphasis on new
pedagogical approaches) as well as collaboration and regular exchanges
with research institutions in the New York area and abroad. Students
whom the PI worked with on this project developed research skills in
cryptographic reasoning and formalizing mathematical proofs as well as
general expertise in scientific and technical presentations. The PI
also co-founded and co-organized the New York Area Crypto Day from Jan
2010 - Aug 2011, a bi-monthly gathering of students, faculty and
research staff in the greater New York area to present and discuss
state-of-the-art research in cryptography.
